 The FCC is, when taken in context, an infringement on free speech. Originally chartered to regulate government owned airwaves and create operating order in that then new technology, it evolved from a commission regulating bandwidth usage to being granted a mandate to regulate bandwidth content. With that combination of original charter and subsequent mandate, I fail to see how one can eliminate political influence on content.
 
 To directly answer your question, the FCC has the power to legally control content of 'their' bandwidth, regardless of who pays for operating expenses, advertisers or subscribers. Yes, I believe that control is an infringement on free speech.

 The FCC has dominion over public airwaves only; it never has over subscription services, which is the only reason for their existence, to get around the FCC.

 
 The government legally owns all domestic airwaves, including subscriber bandwidth with access restricted by technical means and grants permission to use them through the FCC. FCC content control is currently limited to 'public' bandwidth, defined as being broadcast programming open to all receivers without restriction. All it takes to include subscriber paid bandwidth under that control is congressional approval to expand the FCC mandate. Both are, IMO, flagrant violations of free speech, but try fighting city hall.
